subsection.title: Components
subsection.p: We have seen that it can be useful to resolve a vector into horizontal and vertical components. We can also break a vector into components that point in other directions.

Imagine the following experiment: Delbert holds a ball at shoulder height and then drops it, so that it falls to the ground. Francine holds a ball at shoulder height on an inclined ramp, then releases it so that it rolls downhill. Which ball will reach the ground first?

Although gravity causes both balls to speed up, the free-falling ball will reach the ground first. The force of gravity pulls straight down, the same direction as the motion of the free-falling ball, but the rolling ball must move at an angle to the pull of gravity, along the surface of the ramp. Only part of the gravitational force accelerates the rolling ball, and the rest of the force is counteracted by the surface of the ramp. What fraction of the gravitational force causes the ball to roll?

In figure (a), the gravitational force {\bf{F}} is resolved into the sum of two vectors, {\bf{F}}={\bf{u}}+{\bf{v}}, where {\bf{v}} points down the ramp, and {\bf{u}} is perpendicular to the ramp. The magnitude of {\bf{v}} is called the component of {\bf{F}} in the direction of motion, and is denoted by \text{comp}_{\bf{v}}{\bf{F}}. This is the portion of the gravitational force that moves the ball. From figure (b), we see that \text{comp}_{\bf{v}}{\bf{F}} = \|{\bf{F}}\| \cos \theta, where \theta is the angle between {\bf{F}} and {\bf{v}}.

assemblage.title: Component of a Vector

subsection.p: With a little geometry, you can verify that in this example the angle \theta is the complement of the angle of inclination of the ramp, \alpha. (Think of similar triangles.) Now suppose that we increase the angle of inclination. As \alpha increases, \theta decreases, \cos \theta increases, and hence \text{comp}_{\bf{v}}{\bf{F}} increases. This result agrees with our experience: as the ramp gets steeper, the ball rolls faster.

subsection.title: Coordinate Form for Components
subsection.p: In the examples above, we computed the component of a force {\bf{F}} in the direction of a vector {\bf{v}} by knowing the angle between {\bf{F}} and {\bf{v}}. If the vectors are given in coordinate form (that is, {\bf{v}} = a{\bf{i}} + b{\bf{j}}), we may not know the angle between them. Can we compute the component of a vector {\bf{w}} in the direction of {\bf{v}}, in terms of the coordinates of {\bf{v}} and{\bf{w}}?
Suppose {\bf{v}} = a{\bf{i}} + b{\bf{j}} and {\bf{w}} = c{\bf{i}} + d{\bf{j}}, as shown below. We will need to compute the cosine of \theta in terms of a,~ b,~ c,~ and d.
Now we have a fromula for the component of a vector {\bf{w}} in the direction of a vector {\bf{v}}.

assemblage.title: Component of a Vector in Coordinate Form
assemblage.p: If {\bf{v}} = a{\bf{i}} + b{\bf{j}} and {\bf{w}} = c{\bf{i}} + d{\bf{j}}, then the component of {\bf{w}} in the direction of {\bf{w}} is given by \blert{\text{comp}_{\bf{v}}{\bf{w}} =\dfrac{ac+bd}{\|{\bf{v}}\|}}

warning.p: Recall that the "component" of a vector is a scalar. If a vector {\bf{w}} is resolved into two component vectors, {\bf{w}} = {\bf{u}} + {\bf{v}}, its components are the lengths of the vectors {\bf{u}} and {\bf{v}}. The vectors {\bf{u}} and {\bf{v}} themselves are called the vector componentscomponentvector componentvectorcomponent of {\bf{w}}.

Find the vector component of {\bf{w}} in the direction of {\bf{v}}.
Find the vector component of {\bf{w}} perpendicular to {\bf{v}}.

li.p: We use the formula derived above. \text{comp}_{\bf{v}}{\bf{w}} =\dfrac{ac+bd}{\|{\bf{v}}\|} = \dfrac{4(6)+3(2)}{\sqrt{4^2+3^2}} = \dfrac{30}{5} = 6 Remember that the component of {\bf{w}} in the direction of {\bf{v}} is a scalar; it is the length of the projection of {\bf{w}} onto {\bf{v}}.

Because \|{\bf{v}}\| = 5, we scale the components of {\bf{v}} by \dfrac{6}{5} to get {\bf{q}} = \dfrac{6}{5} \left(4{\bf{i}} + 3{\bf{j}}\right) = \dfrac{24}{5}{\bf{i}} + \dfrac{18}{5}{\bf{j}}

subsection.title: The Dot Product
subsection.p: The expression ac+bd, which we encountered above as part of the formula for \text{comp}_{\bf{v}}{\bf{w}}, is quite useful and is given a name; it is called the dot product of the vectors {\bf{v}} = a{\bf{i}} + b{\bf{j}} and {\bf{w}} = c{\bf{i}} + d{\bf{j}}.
It is easy to remember the formula for the dot product if we think of adding the product of the {\bf{i}}-components and the product of the {\bf{j}}-components of the two vectors.

subsection.title: Geometric Meaning of the Dot Product

assemblage.title: Geometric Form for the Dot Product

subsection.p:
The dot product is a way of multiplying two vectors that depends on the angle between them.
If \theta = 0\degree, so that {\bf{v}} and {\bf{w}} point in the same direction, then \cos \theta = 1 and {\bf{v}} \cdot {\bf{w}} is just the product of their lengths, \|{\bf{v}}\|\|{\bf{w}}\|.
If {\bf{v}} and {\bf{w}} are perpendicular, then \cos \theta = 0, so {\bf{v}} \cdot {\bf{w}} = 0. (Two vectors {\bf{v}} and {\bf{w}} are said to be orthogonalorthogonal if their dot product is zero.)
If \theta is between 0\degree and 90\degree, the dot product multiplies the length of {\bf{v}} times the component of {\bf{w}} in the direction of {\bf{v}}.

statement.p: Show that the vectors {\bf{v}} = 2{\bf{i}}+6{\bf{j}} and {\bf{w}} = -9{\bf{i}}+3{\bf{j}} are orthogonal.

solution.p: We compute the dot product of the vectors. {\bf{v}} \cdot {\bf{w}} = 2(-9)+6(3) = 0 Thus, \|{\bf{v}}\|\|{\bf{w}}\| \cos \theta = 0, so {\bf{v}} and {\bf{w}} are orthogonal. Because neither \|{\bf{v}}\| = 0 or \|{\bf{w}}\| = 0, it must be the case that \cos \theta = 0, so \theta = 90\degree or 270\degree.

subsection.p: Using the dot product, we can find the angle between two vectors.

assemblage.title: Angle Between Two Vectors
assemblage.p: The angle \theta between two vectors {\bf{v}} and {\bf{w}} is given by \blert{\cos \theta = \dfrac{{\bf{v}} \cdot {\bf{w}}}{\|{\bf{v}}\| \|{\bf{w}}\|}}

statement.p: Find the angle between the vectors {\bf{u}} = -3{\bf{i}}+2{\bf{j}} and {\bf{v}} = 5{\bf{i}}+3{\bf{j}}.

solution.p: We first compute {\bf{u}} \cdot {\bf{v}} and the magnitude of each vector.

Then we apply the formula for \cos \theta. \begin{aligned}[t] \cos \theta \amp = \dfrac{{\bf{v}} \cdot {\bf{w}}}{\|{\bf{v}}\| \|{\bf{w}}\|} = \dfrac{-9}{\sqrt{13}\sqrt{34}} = -0.4281\\ \theta \amp = \cos^{-1}(-0.4281) = 115.35\degree\\ \end{aligned} The angle between the vectors is 115.35\degree.
